numbered_ace_sentences: 1. I notice an extreme increase in the admission odds for legacy applicants.
2. I notice an increase in the admission odds for applicants whose parents are in the top 1% to 5% by income.
3. I notice no change in admission odds by income below the top 5%.
4. I notice that income has a much greater effect on admission odds for legacy applicants than for non-legacy applicants.
5. I wonder why there is such a difference between non-legacy applicants and legacy applicants.
6. A legacy applicant is an applicant whose parent attended the college.
7. I expect that the college accepts the best applicants.
8. I wonder why income can affect admissions so greatly.
9. I wonder whether higher-income applicants have more support to build a better application.
10. I wonder whether income is part of the admissions calculations.
11. I notice that income reduces admission odds for a non-legacy applicant until the top 5% by income.
12. I notice that income increases admission odds for a legacy applicant.
13. Admission to college is very important to me.
14. Admission to college is very important to many other students in my community.
15. Most students in my community are not legacy applicants.
16. If non-legacy applicants have a great disadvantage, then the hopes of many students in my district will be damaged.
17. My district is split by parents' financial status.
18. I think that parents' financial status should not affect admissions.
19. I think that the most supported kids are often not the smartest students.
20. I think that the most supported kids are often not the hardest working students.
21. The headline is: College Admissions Skewed: The Effects of Income and Legacy.
